products.title: MAIN PRODUCTS
products.subtitle: High-quality raw materials for livestock and industry

corn.name: CORN
corn.description:
Overview

Corn Silage is a product fermented from fresh whole corn plants (including stems, leaves, and ears) under anaerobic conditions. The fermentation process helps preserve natural nutrients and creates aromatic feed that is appealing to livestock.

Outstanding Features

  • Raw Material: Fresh corn harvested at wax maturity stage
  • Moisture: 65-70%
  • Crude Protein: 8-9%
  • Fiber: 20-22%
  • pH: 3.8-4.2 (stable, long-term storage)

Applications

Main feed for dairy cattle, beef cattle, goats, and sheep. Helps improve milk yield and effective weight gain.

Products meet export standards for markets in Japan, South Korea, and the Middle East.

sawdust.name: SAWDUST
sawdust.description:
Raw Materials

Pine Sawdust Block is compressed from 100% fresh pine sawdust, without mixing, ensuring uniform quality.

Characteristics

ParameterValue
Block Size30×30×15cm
Weight10-12kg/block
Moisture≤ 15%
Compression Density≥ 650kg/m³
ColorNatural light yellow

Main Uses

  • Growing medium for orchids, premium flowers
  • Livestock bedding material
  • Raw material for pellet production
  • Moisture absorption in warehouses

others.name: OTHERS
others.description:
Flexible According to Needs

We provide various other agricultural by-products according to specific customer requirements. With our widespread collection system and advanced processing technology, we can meet diverse needs.

Potential Products

  • Coffee husks, rice husks
  • Cassava residue, soybean residue
  • Vegetable and fruit by-products
  • Compressed straw pellets
  • Various types of silage grass

Consulting Services

Our technical team is ready to advise on:

  • Selecting suitable raw materials
  • Processing and preservation technology
  • Designing feed formulations
  • By-product utilization solutions
Contact us immediately for consultation on the most suitable products for your needs!

corn_silage.description:
Corn silage is a popular forage for ruminant animals because it is high in energy and digestibility and is easily adapted to mechanization from the stand-crop to time of feeding.

Corn silage should have a light, pleasant smell with only a slight vinegar odor. It should be slightly brown to dark green. If it is dark brown or has an odor that is fruity, yeasty, burnt or rancid (butyric acid), excessive heating or improper fermentation has occurred. Knowledge of the silage process often explains why some silage may be of poor quality.

Process:
1/ HARVESTING
Corn should be harvested for silage after the ear is well dented but before the leaves turn brown and dry. The quantity and quality of corn silage are at their peak in this stage of development. The ear has accumulated most of its potential feeding value, but there has been little loss from the leaves and stalks. After the dent stage, feeding value of corn stalks and leaves decreases while field losses increase.

2/ DRYING
During Silage preparation, the grass is allowed to wilt in the field for a few hours to reduce the moisture content to around 60-75% as this is the optimum level. If the grass is left out longer, it may get too dry, or it may get rained on – and both these will reduce the efficiency of the fermentation.

3/ CUTTING
Corn silage should be cut into particles 1/2 to 3/4 inches in length. Particles of this size will pack more firmly in the silo and are more palatable to cattle. Very finely cut silage may be made with a recutter. This will increase the amount of dry matter that can be stored in a silo.

4/ FERMENTATION
Compress the grass to eject the oxygen more efficiently. This is important because the microorganisms especially, lactic acid bacteria, grow best under anaerobic (oxygen-free) conditions. When oxygen remains, plant enzymes and other bacteria react with the plant sugars and proteins to make energy, thus reducing the amount of nutrients in the final product.

Packing style: Jumbo bag 650kg x 40 bags (26MT)/40 HC

corn_cob_meal.description:
Corn cob meal is a fertilizer made from dried and ground corn cobs. It is mainly used as feed for cattle and other livestock and as a culture medium for mushroom. Use especifically for mushroom production, including all varieties, and for feeding livestock, including cattle, pigs, goats, chickens and many more.

Process:
1/ HARVESTING
Corn cobs are purchased from relatives and brought to the factory. Corn cobs are dried and crushed to produce corn cob meal.

2/ CRUSHING
Its production steps include drying the corn cob, separating the corn from the cob, drying the cob, crushing the cob with a machine.

3/ COMPLETING
After the crushing, drying the cob and putting into a PP bag, placed on pallets and packed into 40'HC containers to be pulled to the port of export.

Packing style: PP bags 30kg x 840 bags (25.2MT)/40 HC

corn_cob_pellet.description:
Corn pellets are made from discarded parts of corn such as corn husks, cobs. These materials will be deheated, dried and produced into corn pellets.

Process:
1/ HARVESTING
Corn cobs are purchased from relatives and brought to the factory. The purchased corn cob must have a moisture content of about 12-15% to be able to be put into press into cubes. For corn cob with higher humidity, it is necessary to go through the dryer system to dry to reach the above moisture content.

2/ PRESSING
After reaching the specified humidity, corn cob will be put on the conveyor belt into the raw material intake mouth of the block press. Then the material will be compressed with high pressure to produce pressed corn pulp.

3/ COMPLETING
After the finished product is pressed corn pulp blocks, they will be folded into jumbo bags, placed on pallets and packed into 40'HC containers to be pulled to the port of export.

Packing style: Jumbo bag 650kg x 40 bags (26 MT)/40HC

pine_sawdust_block.description:
Pine wood sawdust is a type of organic material that comes from the manufacturing and processing sectors. For farming and animal bedding, pine wood sawdust is quite useful. After a lengthy period of planting, pine wood sawdust enriches dry, hard soil with more nutrients. Additionally, pine wood sawdust gives the animal a tidy and cozy environment to live.

Process:
1/ COLLECTING
Get pine wood sawdust: purchase and bring to the factory.

2/ CLEANING
Clean the pine wood sawdust: Soak the pine wood sawdust in lime water to balance PH in the soil and eliminate pathogens better.

3/ CULTIVATING
Cultivate the soil with processed sawdust: Mix the sawdust into the soil and then let the mixture sunbathe in 2-3 days to kill the pests in the soil.

Packing style: Jumbo bag 570 - 600kg x 40 bags (23-24MT)/40 HC

acacia_sawdust_pellet.description:
Acacia sawdust is made by cutting, grinding, drilling, sanding, or otherwise pulverizing natural acacia wood with saws or other tools. It consists of fine particles of wood. Acacia sawdust is widely used in agriculture, especially in mushroom cultivation. In addition, acacia tree sawdust has excellent moisture retention properties, which helps reduce evaporation and maintain soil temperature. Acacia sawdust has recently become a common ingredient in animal feed. The reason is that acacia sawdust undergoes a simple processing stage that removes impurities that are not good for the animal's health.

Process:
1/ COLLECTING
Get acacia wood sawdust: purchase and bring to the factory.

2/ CRUSHING
Crushing large-sized ingredients. These large-sized materials will be fed into the grinding system to grind into suitably sized pieces of sawdust (<5mm is usually the general standard).

3/ MOISTURE BALANCE AND PELLETIZING
Moisture balance for sawdust. Acacia wood sawdust pellet compression.

4/ COOLING AND COMPLETING
Cool - Sawdust pellets after passing through the compressor will be winch directly into the conveyor cooler. After cooling, the finished product will be put in giant bag, placed on pallets and packed into 40'HC containers to be pulled to the port of export.

Packing style: Jumbo bag 650kg x 40 bags (26MT)/40HC
